results.title: The Tender game
results.creator_credit: John Hubley, Edward Harrison and Storyboard
results.brief_description: Produced by the group which also made HARLEM WEDNESDAY and MOONBIRD. Using abstract shapes and colours and animated sketches, it tells amusingly of a girl and boy who meet in a park and, after shy advances and retreats, leave happily together. Music performed by the Oscar Peterson Trio with vocals by Ella Fitzgerald.

results.title: The Tenant of Wildfell Hall
results.creator_credit: Mike Barker, Suzan Harrison, WGBH (Boston), Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and BBC
results.brief_description: Anne Bronte’s novel of an unhappy marriage deals with the themes of self-sacrifice, adulterous passion and redemption set amongst the rugged but beautiful landscape of the Yorkshire Dales. Helen Graham, a widow with a young son, is the new tenant of Wildfell Hall. Her radical views and her aloofness attracts the local young squire Gilbert Markham but despite the attraction, Helen has a secret which prevents their love from blossoming. Starring Tara Fitzgerald, Toby Stephens and Rupert Graves.

results.title: The Tenant
results.creator_credit: Roman Polanski, Marianne Productions and Andrew Braunsberg
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Richard Topor, “The Tenant” is a psychological horror film by Roman Polanski which can also be read as a deeply disturbed personal work about a man’s disintegration in the face of death and tragedy. (There are obvious parallels to be drawn by the mental disintegration of the film’s main character, Trelkovsky - played by Polanski himself - to the crisis suffered by the director when his wife and unborn child were brutally slaughtered by the infamous Charles Manson cult). Polanski’s work from the beginning of his career has seen him play mischievously and surrealistically with the themes of mental illness, hauntings and transvestitism, but in “The Tenant”, the whole world which Trelkovsky inhabits seems to be riddled with varying degrees of evil and repressed violence. He is a new tenant in an old Baroque Parisian hotel and the last occupant in his room attempted suicide by jumping from the building. Trelkovsky meets her on the day of her death: the memory of her anguished screaming will reverberate with him for the rest of his life. The cast includes Isabelle Adjani, Melvyn Douglas, Shelley Winters and Lila Kedrova, and the sombre lighting and cinematography is by noted Swedish cinematographer, Sven Nykvist. As always, Polanski proves an effective and imaginative master of the horror genre. Note: “The Tenant” is a USA/French co-production in which the French actors are dubbed into English.

results.creator_credit: David Baker, Roger Mirams and Pacific Films

results.title: The Ten days that shook the world
results.creator_credit: Serghej Bondarchiuk, Nello Santi, Conacite Dos and Mosfilm
results.brief_description: It is 1917…the brink of the Russian Revolution. American journalist John Reed is there to write about it, to love it, and survive it, if he can. Now, almost 70 years later, and at a cost of over $50 million, the event has become a spectacular motion picture. Shot entirely on location in Russia, including magnificent scenes inside the Winter Palace, and with the entire Russian 3rd Army as extras, master filmmaker Serghei Bondarchuk has created one of the most spectacular motion pictures ever filmed.

results.title: The Ten Commandments
results.creator_credit: Cecil B. DeMille and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Cecil B. DeMille’s classic Biblical epic, with a galaxy of stars led by Charlton Heston as Moses and Yul Brynner as Pharoah. It is the story of the life of Moses from birth and abandonment through manhood, slavery and the trials of turning his back on a privileged life in the Pharoah’s household and leading his people, the Jews out of Egypt and to freedom. Filmed in Egypt and the Sinai with one of the biggest sets ever constructed for a motion picture, this is a unique and motion picture experience with the parting of the Red Sea and the writing of the tablets being unforgettable highlights. Oscar winning special effects.

results.title: The Temptation of Mr Prokouk
results.creator_credit: Karel Zeman, Jaroslav Novotny and Czechoslovak State Films
results.brief_description: A puppet figure of Prokouk is shown building his house. The demon of alcohol comes to tempt him and for a time he yields but he realises that excessive drinking does not agree with his plans for setting up a house of his own. He resists and throws bricks at the demon smashing it to pieces.

results.title: The Temples of Malta
results.creator_credit: P.J. Grimsey, D.C. Chipperfield and Boulton-Hawker Films
results.brief_description: During the period 3000 to 2000 B.C., the peoples of the small islands of Malta and Gozo built some remarkable megalithic temples of unique design. These little known temples, together with the rock-cut tombs indicate a high level of culture unparalleled in Western Europe at the time.

results.title: The Tell-tale heart
results.brief_description: Adaption of the Edgar Allan Poe tale of a manservant (Alex Cord), quite mad but telling the story to convince us of his rationality, who feels compelled to murder his bedridden master (Sam Jaffee), driven by obsession with the old man’s blind eye. Suitable for upper secondary level.
